I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The  Government  of  the  People’s  Republic  of  China  (PRC)  requested  the  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) to provide technical assistance (TA) to help make the country’s urban 
pension system more sustainable.1 A TA fact-finding mission to Beijing on 23–24 July 2013 
reached  agreement  with  the  government  on  the  impact,  outcome,  outputs,  implementation 
arrangements, costs, financial arrangements, and terms of reference for the consulting services 
of the TA. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.2 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  The aging of its population is a critical challenge to development in the PRC. In 2010, 
the working-age ratio in the PRC stood at 72.4% and had increased by 13% in the last 3 
decades.3 This suggested that the country’s rapidly growing economy had benefitted from a 
demographic dividend during this period.4 This dividend is expected to begin declining in about 
2015. In addition, the elderly dependency ratio in the PRC is projected to rise from 11.3% in 
2010 to 17% in 2020 and 24% in 2030, which is above current levels in such major developed 
countries as Canada and the United States.5 Meanwhile, rapid urbanization in the last decade 
has greatly increased the urban population in the PRC, which reached 51% of the overall 
population in 2011. This growth is expected to continue.  
 
3.  The rapidity and extent of this aging trend raise concerns about the sustainability of the 
PRC’s pension systems. The country’s urban and rural populations are covered by separate 
pension systems. The urban pension system was established in 1997.6 The rural system has 
been introduced since 2009.7 Sustainability is not a major concern for the rural pension since it 
is designed largely as a social welfare system and requires significant fiscal subsidies from the 
central and local governments. The urban pension system consists of a pay-as-you-go (PAYG) 
scheme and individual accounts, which forms a primary economic protection for the majority of 
the elderly people in the urban areas of the PRC.8 Although the design of the country’s pension 
systems provides for universal coverage, this is not yet in place. Achieving full coverage will 
increase  public  expenditures  and  put  additional  stress  on  the  current  pension  system. 
Therefore, there is an urgent need for the PRC to examine the pension system’s sustainability in 
anticipation of the full impact of the demographic transition. 
 
4.  A key factor affecting sustainability of a pension system is the expected duration of

6  The government established a nationwide basic pension insurance system for the urban population based on 
State Council Document 26 issued in 1997. 
7  Pilots of a new rural pension system have begun in 2009. 
8  Pay as-you-go (PAYG) is a scheme financing defined benefits. Under this scheme, benefits are paid from current 
contributions and taxes. Individual accounts are the funded financing scheme. Under the individual accounts 
scheme, the defined contribution is funded or saved in the individual account.

2  
retirement, which determines length of the period over which pension benefits must be paid.9  A 
realistic estimate of life expectancy after retirement age is important to keep a pension system 
sustainable.  In  member  countries  of  the  Organisation  for  Economic  Co-operation  and 
Development (OECD), average life expectancy after formal retirement age was 18.5 years for 
men and 23.3 years for women as of 2010.10 Based on the PRC’s current formal retirement age, 
life expectancy after retirement age is 20.7 years for men and 25.7 years for women.11 To 
maintain the sustainability of their pension systems, most OECD countries have committed to 
raise the retirement age to bring it more in line with increases in life expectancy. The PRC may 
also need to review the formal retirement age on the ongoing efforts to strengthen sustainability 
of its urban pension system. 
 
5.  In addition, the effective retirement age is closely related to the years of contribution 
required for full pension benefits.12  Some countries set both a minimum number of contribution 
years  for  pension  benefit  eligibility  and  contribution  years  for  qualification  for  full  benefits. 
Benefits for pensioners whose contribution years are less than the required years for the full 
benefits are reduced based on the specified calculation. The required contribution years for full 
pension benefits vary across countries. For example, it is about 10 years in the United States, 
25 years in Turkey, 30 years in the United Kingdom, 40 years in Japan, and 41 years in France. 
An individual needs to contribute for 15 years to qualify for a PAYG urban pension under the 
current pension system in the PRC.13 In general, the short contribution period requirement 
motivates  people  to  retire  before  the  formal  retirement  age.  Setting  conditions  for  early 
retirement, such as a minimum eligible age and reduced benefits, can have an effect on the 
choice of the effective retirement age. The levels of the contributions required and the benefits 
paid  out  are  other  key  factors  in  determining  a  pension  scheme’s  sustainability.  These 
parameters also need to be examined to strengthen the PRC’s urban pension system. 
 
6.  As urban pension schemes are managed at province and municipality levels in the PRC, 
there are no reliable aggregated projections on net pension liabilities for the whole country.14 
Net liabilities are not recognized in accounting terms until the obligation to pay arises. Under 
PAYG  schemes,  the  contributions  are  used  to  pay  the  current  pension  recipients  but  not 
accumulated for future pension payments for the contributors. Therefore, net pension liabilities 
may arise under the PAYG scheme, if the number of pensioners increases and becomes more 
than contributors due to a change in demographic structure. Liabilities generally do not arise 
under  the  individual  account  scheme  because  the  individual’s  contribution  is  saved  in  the 
individual account to fund the future benefit payment. However, the current PRC individual 
account scheme assumes post-retirement life to be 120 months. If the individual lives longer 
than  120  months,  the PAYG  scheme  is  required  to  continue  financing  pension  payments. 
Therefore, the individual account scheme has also become partially unfunded in the PRC 
because of the increase in life expectancy.   
 
7.  The lack of reliable projections on aggregated liabilities makes it difficult to properly 
assess the sustainability of the PRC’s urban pension system. It also raises concerns about

3
whether the National Social Security Fund (NSSF), established in 2000 as a national long-term 
strategic reserve fund to meet future pension obligations, has enough resources to meet those 
obligations.15 Total NSSF assets increased rapidly during 2000–2011 from 0.2% to 1.8% of 
gross domestic product. It is considered important that the NSSF is adequately resourced when 
it takes on responsibility for major pension expenditures in about 2030, but its ability to meet 
these needs cannot be known without reliable projections of pension liabilities. The PRC needs 
to develop these projections to assess the sustainability of the urban pension system and the 
asset level of the NSSF. 
 
8.  ADB’s country partnership and strategy, 2011–2015 for the PRC promotes inclusive 
growth as one of its three strategic pillars.16 A sound pension system will provide economic 
protection for the elderly, which contributes to achieving the inclusive growth. The purpose of 
the TA will provide the Ministry of Human Resources and Social Security (MOHRSS) with 
recommendations  for  strengthening  the  sustainability  of  the  urban  pension  system.  It  will 
continue ADB’s support for pension reforms in the PRC since the mid-1990s.17 ADB’s previous 
support helped expand the rural pension system and improved its administration. The proposed 
TA provides further assistance to MOHRSS in strengthening the sustainability of the urban 
pension system.  
 
9.  The TA will examine the following key issues: (i) the adequate retirement age; (ii) the 
number of required years of contributions, and the adequate levels of contributions and benefits; 
(iii) disincentives for early retirement; (iv) the projection of pension liabilities and of the scale of 
the NSSF’s future assets; and (v) public opinion on potential pension reforms. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
10.  The impact will be improved sustainability of the urban pension system while ensuring 
adequate benefits. This will be measured by adoption of recommendations that emerge from the 
TA. The outcome will be improved framework of the urban pension system for strengthening its 
sustainability.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
11.  The TA will achieve the outcome through six major outputs:   
 
(i)  Analysis of the sustainability of the PRC urban pension system with a focus on 
retirement  age,  required  years  of  contribution  payment,  disincentives  for  early 
retirement,  and  the  levels  of  contributions  and  benefits.  The  analysis  will  also 
examine the impact of unifying the retirement age between men and women. 
(ii)  Analysis  of  international  practices  on  strengthening  pension  sustainability.  The 
analysis will focus on: retirement age, including gender difference in retirement age; 
the required years of contribution payment; disincentives for early retirement; and

(iii)  Projection of pension liabilities and the NSSF asset levels. 
(iv)  Survey of public opinions on potential pension reforms.  
(v)  Knowledge  products  summarizing  key  policy  lessons  and  recommendations  on 
pension sustainability. 
(vi)  Capacity  development  of  relevant  government  officials  to  enhance  their 
understanding on the issues related to pension sustainability and pension liability 
projections. 
 
12.  To deliver the planned outputs, the consulting team leader will develop a detailed work 
plan in consultation with the MOHRSS. The consulting team will analyze the sustainability of the 
PRC pension system for urban employees.18 The survey to be conducted by the team in several 
provinces will investigate public opinion on potential pension reforms. Based on the analyses, 
the consulting team will formulate recommendations for strengthening the sustainability of the 
urban pension system in the PRC, providing scenarios for the pension liabilities based on the 
options proposed.  
 
13.  The TA will include an international study tour to observe international good practices. 
Workshops will be organized at various stages of project implementation to enhance awareness 
of key issues for the relevant government officials. The workshops will include but not be limited 
to an interim workshop and a final workshop. The MOHRSS will also ensure that finalized reports 
on the analyses and the recommendations are circulated to all relevant government agencies.    
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
14.  The TA is estimated to cost the equivalent of $430,000, of which $400,000 will be 
financed on a grant basis by ADB's Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources). 
The government will provide counterpart support in the form of office accommodation, data and 
documents for the consultants; counterpart staff; logistical support, including costs of selected 
translation and meeting arrangements; and other related services. Detailed cost estimates are 
in Appendix 2.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
15.  The TA will be implemented over 24 months from 21 October 2013 to 20 October 2015. 
The MOHRSS will be the executing agency.  
16.  The TA will cover remuneration, travel, and per diem of consultants, as well as the costs 
of workshops, seminars, the study tour, and miscellaneous expenses. Disbursements under the 
TA will be done in accordance with ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, 
as amended from time to time). The executing agency will prepare an advance payment facility 
to  implement  the  activities  of  workshops  and  study  tour.  All  procurement  will  be  done  in 
accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2013, as amended from time to time).   
 
17.  Five  consultants  will  be  engaged  individually:  an  international  pension  insurance

executing agency will provide the consultants with the information they need about the PRC

19.  The project-specific indicators and targets in the design and monitoring framework will 
be monitored by the executing agency, with ADB support. Policy dialogue will be maintained 
with  the  relevant  government  agencies  and  project-specific  issues  will  be  taken  up  with 
government counterparts during review missions. Technical milestones will be monitored by 
reports to be prepared by the consultants and reviewed by the executing agency and the ADB 
project officer. Milestones related to TA implementation will be monitored by the team leader. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The technical assistance (TA) will require 22.5 person-months of consulting services, 
comprising the services of two international consultants for a total of 7.5 person-months and 
three  national  consultants  for  a  total  of  15.0  person-months.  The  international  consultants 
should  preferably  have  a  postgraduate  degree,  or  the  equivalent,  and  about  12  years  of 
international experience in their respective fields of expertise. The national consultants should 
preferably  have  a  master’s  degree,  or  the  equivalent,  and  about  8  years  of  professional 
experience  in  their  respective  fields  of  expertise.  The  international  consultants  will  be 
responsible primarily for providing advisory services and recommendations for policy makers 
based on international experience and practice. In addition, the international consultants will 
serve as peer reviewers on reports on technical issues and other documents translated from 
Chinese into English. The international consultants will review the translated reports to ensure 
that technical issues are adequately addressed. The international consultants will work with the 
national  consultants  in  cooperation  with  the  designated staff  of  the  executing  agency,  the 
Ministry of Human Resources and Social Security, to prepare reports and recommendations. 
National  consultants  will  be  responsible  for  the  technical  aspects  of  implementing  the  TA 
project. The team of experts will be selected on the basis of individual consultant, in accordance 
with the Asian Development Bank (ADB) Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2013, as 
amended from time to time). 
 
2.  The international and national consultants will be responsible for the timely submission 
of  TA  outputs  and  deliverables  and  will  organize  and  implement  all  TA  activities.  The 
consultants  will  (i)  analyze  the  sustainability  of  the  urban  pension  system  in  the  People’s 
Republic of China (PRC). The analysis will focus on (a) retirement age, including the issues of 
gender difference in retirement age; (b) the required years of contribution, (c) disincentives for 
early retirement, and (d) contribution and benefit levels; (ii) review and analyze international 
practices on strengthening pension sustainability with a focus in those same areas; (iii) project 
pension liabilities and assess the National Social Security Fund (NSSF) asset levels; (iv)survey 
and analyze public opinion on the potential pension reforms; (v) produce a knowledge product 
summarizing  key  policy  lessons  and  recommendations  on  pension  sustainability;  and  (vi) 
organize  and  participate  in  workshops  or  seminars,  and  prepare  appropriate  presentation 
materials, as necessary. All reports are to be of high quality and produced in English, with 
copies  in  Chinese.  Precise  work  timelines  and  deliverables  with  dates  will  be  defined  at 
inception, documented in the final inception report, and agreed upon with the executing agency 
and  ADB.  Regular  monitoring  and  reporting of  costs,  time  schedule,  risks,  quality,  human 
resources, and communications will be performed by the ADB TA project officer and the support 
team, which will include local project officers and consultants hired under the TA. 
 
A.  International Consultants  
 
3.  Pension insurance expert (5 person-months). This international expert should have 
substantial expertise and sufficient experience in pension insurance systems. The expert must 
be familiar with the sustainability of a pension system and pension liabilities. Knowledge of the 
PRC’s urban pension system will be preferable. The expert will perform the following tasks: 
 
(i)  The expert will work closely with the other consultants, the executing agency, 
and  ADB  and  be  responsible  for  delivering  a  technical  report,  a  knowledge 
product, an inception report, and a final report. 
(ii)  The expert will review key contributions of other organizations regarding the 
sustainability of the PRC urban pension system. The expert will analyze the

include key policy advice for strengthening pension sustainability and will be

(iv)  The expert will assist the national sample survey expert in preparing the survey

(v)  The expert will work closely with the team leader to draft and complete an

(viii)  The expert will make presentations at sessions of the workshops and prepare

4.  Pension liabilities expert (2.5 person-months). The international expert should have 
substantial expertise and sufficient experience in the projection of pension liabilities. Knowledge 
of the PRC urban pension system will be preferable. The expert will perform the following tasks: 
 
(i)  The expert will prepare the list of the data and information needed to project the 
pension liabilities for the PRC urban pension system and to assess the NSSF
